Model structure

Corson N. Areshenkoff

2024-08-06

model_structure.Rmd

iowamodels is designed to implement a broad class of reinforcement learning models of the Iowa gambling task, which take the following general form:

In the task, the subject is presented with a set of KK decks, each of which produces a reward or loss with some unknown frequency. Typically, the subject is instructed only to maximize their total earnings by the end of the task, which they must do by learning which of the decks is the most profitable over the long term.

Upon selecting a deck, the subject sees an outcome xx, which they assign some utility u(x)u(x). Note that, in many implementations of the task, the subject experiences both a gain gg and a loss ll, and the utility function assumes that the utility of the outcome is some weighted combination of these two.

The assumption is that the subject maintains a valuation V=(v1,v2,v3,v4)V = (v_1,v_2,v_3,v_4) for each deck, corresponding to its expected utility. Upon selecting a deck dd, the subject observes an outcome with utility uu and updates the corresponding deck valuation through some updating function. The probability of selecting deck dd on the next trial is computed with a softmax function

P(d)=eθVd∑i=14eθVi P(d) = \frac{e^{\theta V_d}}{\sum_{i=1}^4 e^{\theta V_i}}

where θ\theta is a temperature parameter controlling the stochasticity of the decision rule. The temperature schedule (i.e. how it evolves over the course of the task) is controlled by a temperature function θ(t)\theta(t), where tt is the current trial.

Specifying a model

Models implemented by iowamodels require specifying the utility, updating, and temperature functions. The package implements several common versions of each, based on models which have been commonly reported in the literature. Each function is identified by a keyword, and utility/updating/temperature functions can be mixed and matched. Detailed information about available options is given in the respective articles.
